docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A Nov. 13 news analysis suggests that during her trip to the West Bank there was tension between Hillary Rodham Clinton's role as first lady and her role as a potential candidate for the United States Senate. But this rests on a faulty premise: that views of the Middle East peace effort from the White House and from the Senate are necessarily different.
docs.abstract: Robin Anthony Elliott letter on Nov 13 news analysis holds Hillary Clinton's tardy reubke of Suha Arafat's anti-Israel diatribe was appropriate in her roles as both first lady and potential Senate candidate

docs.lead_paragraph: I think Elizabeth ought to debate Hillary." Bob Dole The air crackles with history and the baritones of network anchors. Everyone has crowded into the Cincinnati convention center for the First Ladies Debate, jointly sponsored by Martha Stewart Enterprises and Archer Daniels Midland. The moderator in the Reds sweat suit, Marge Schott, finishes a vodka and water, stubs out a Carlton, checks to see if her dog, Schottzie, needs to tinkle or poo, and gets right to it.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Hillary Rachelle Haberman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Haberman of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married last evening to Jeffrey Scott Suchman, the son of Flora Suchman of Harrison, N.Y., and Leslie Suchman of Manhattan. Rabbi Arthur Schneier officiated at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof in New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: Colorado's nine electors must vote for Hillary Clinton because she won the state's popular vote, a judge ruled Tuesday, effectively stopping the state's electors from joining a longshot effort to unite with Republicans behind a compromise presidential candidate other than Donald Trump.

headline.print_headline: Judge Orders Colorado Electors to Vote for Hillary Clinton
headline.main: Judge Orders Colorado Electors to Vote for Hillary Clinton

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s strongest advantage isn’t her war chest, fame or gender. It’s Republicans.
docs.abstract: Frank Bruni Op-Ed column suggests that Hillary Rodham Clinton's greatest asset at this early point in 2016 presidential contest is that she is not any of the Republican presidential candidates, whom polls show voters seem to dislike.
